questions.stem: A 6-year-old boy has a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections beginning at age 2. He was hospitalized twice for pneumonia and once for meningococcal bacteremia. Between infections he is well and growing appropriately. Vaccinations are up to date. Physical exam is unremarkable. Labs today show normal absolute lymphocyte count, normal neutrophils, and low C3 with undetectable C5–C9 hemolytic activity. Blood glucose and HIV test are normal. His mother asks what the immune system is “supposed to do” and why her son keeps getting these infections despite healthy habits. Which statement best captures the principal purpose of the immune system as illustrated by this child’s presentation?

options.A: — Correct.
options.B: Central tolerance is essential but does not explain recurrent bacterial infections with complement defects.
options.C: Tissue repair is a consequence of injury, not the primary immune mandate in this scenario.
options.D: Tumor surveillance is real but not the issue in a child with invasive bacteria.
options.E: Memory is adaptive immunity’s feature; terminal complement deficiency impairs immediate innate defense, not memory.

rationales.E: Protect the host by eliminating microbes while limiting collateral tissue damage Why this is right: Recurrent infections with encapsulated bacteria and Neisseria, along with terminal complement deficiency, highlight the core role of immunity in host defense against pathogens. Complement participates in opsonization and MAC-mediated lysis, particularly important for Neisseria. The overarching purpose is microbial elimination with regulated inflammation to prevent bystander injury. This case exemplifies failure of a defense arm rather than a tolerance or repair defect. Why the others are wrong:

questions.expl: A — Protect the host by eliminating microbes while limiting collateral tissue damage Why this is right: Recurrent infections with encapsulated bacteria and Neisseria, along with terminal complement deficiency, highlight the core role of immunity in host defense against pathogens. Complement participates in opsonization and MAC-mediated lysis, particularly important for Neisseria. The overarching purpose is microbial elimination with regulated inflammation to prevent bystander injury. This case exemplifies failure of a defense arm rather than a tolerance or repair defect. Why the others are wrong: A. — Correct. B. Central tolerance is essential but does not explain recurrent bacterial infections with complement defects. C. Tissue repair is a consequence of injury, not the primary immune mandate in this scenario. D. Tumor surveillance is real but not the issue in a child with invasive bacteria. E. Memory is adaptive immunity’s feature; terminal complement deficiency impairs immediate innate defense, not memory.

questions.stem: A 28-year-old woman develops progressive dyspnea and nonproductive cough 8 weeks after returning from a desert camping trip. She has no fever or weight loss. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar fullness and reticulonodular opacities. Bronchoscopy with BAL reveals CD4+ T-lymphocyte predominance. Transbronchial biopsy demonstrates noncaseating granulomas. She asks how her “immune system that’s supposed to protect me” is now causing symptoms. Which concept best explains the link between normal immune purpose and this clinical disease?

options.A: Th2 skewing fits atopic disease, not granulomas.
options.B: TLR4 deficiency would predispose to Gram-negative sepsis, not granulomatous lung disease.
options.C: Dysregulated chronic inflammation from persistent antigen, forming granulomas that impair function
options.D: Autoantibodies to surfactant are not a typical cause of this picture.
options.E: Immune complex alveolitis would show vasculitic features and complement consumption, not organized granulomas.

rationales.E: Dysregulated chronic inflammation from persistent antigen, forming granulomas that impair function Why this is right: Granulomatous inflammation represents a persistent T cell–macrophage response to poorly cleared antigens, linking host defense to tissue dysfunction. The immune system’s protective mechanisms (Th1 cytokines, macrophage activation) can cause organ damage when persistent. Noncaseating granulomas and BAL CD4+ predominance support immune-mediated granulomatous disease. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: A 19-year-old man presents with anaphylaxis minutes after eating a peanut-containing cookie. He has a history of childhood eczema and seasonal rhinitis. Vitals after epinephrine are stable. Serum tryptase is transiently elevated. He asks why this happened “so fast.” Which statement best describes how the immune system’s normal purpose can, in this case, produce clinical disease?

options.A: CTL responses are delayed and peptide-specific; not the mechanism of anaphylaxis.
options.B: TLR responses alone don’t explain IgE-mediated immediate reactions.
options.C: Preformed, high-affinity IgE on mast cells triggering rapid mediator release to a non-danger antigen
options.D: MAC formation is not central to anaphylaxis.
options.E: NK “missing-self” is unrelated to IgE allergy.

rationales.E: Preformed, high-affinity IgE on mast cells triggering rapid mediator release to a non-danger antigen Why this is right: In IgE-mediated food allergy, prior sensitization leads to IgE bound to FcεRI on mast cells. Re-exposure cross-links IgE, causing immediate degranulation (histamine, tryptase) and anaphylaxis—an inappropriate application of a defense pathway against parasites/toxins to a harmless food antigen. The speed reflects pre-armed effector cells. Why the others are wrong:

questions.expl: E — Preformed, high-affinity IgE on mast cells triggering rapid mediator release to a non-danger antigen Why this is right: In IgE-mediated food allergy, prior sensitization leads to IgE bound to FcεRI on mast cells. Re-exposure cross-links IgE, causing immediate degranulation (histamine, tryptase) and anaphylaxis—an inappropriate application of a defense pathway against parasites/toxins to a harmless food antigen. The speed reflects pre-armed effector cells. Why the others are wrong: A. CTL responses are delayed and peptide-specific; not the mechanism of anaphylaxis. B. TLR responses alone don’t explain IgE-mediated immediate reactions. D. MAC formation is not central to anaphylaxis. E. NK “missing-self” is unrelated to IgE allergy.
questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: A 34-year-old woman has fatigue, arthralgias, photosensitive rash, and oral ulcers. Labs: anemia, thrombocytopenia, low C3/C4, positive anti-dsDNA, proteinuria. Renal biopsy shows granular immune complex deposition with subendothelial “wire-loop” lesions. Which statement best links the immune system’s normal purposes to the clinical disease seen here?

options.A: — Correct (selected).
options.B: NK surveillance is more about tumors/viruses.
options.C: Th17 and eosinophils do not explain immune complex GN.
options.D: MAC deficiency affects bacterial killing; the issue is tolerance, not MAC.
options.E: TLR3 viral sensing is unrelated to SLE nephritis pathogenesis. Subtopic: Detection and Response to Danger Signals

rationales.E: Failure of peripheral tolerance leading to autoantibodies that form tissue-depositing immune complexes Why this is right: SLE features breakdown of tolerance with autoantibody formation (e.g., anti-dsDNA). Immune complexes deposit in tissues, activate complement, and drive inflammation, linking adaptive immune purpose (specific recognition) to immunopathology when misdirected. Hypocomplementemia supports consumption by immune complex deposition. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: A 52-year-old man sustains a crush injury to his calf. Within hours, he develops fever and localized swelling without signs of infection. Serum shows elevated HMGB1 and uric acid near the wound bed. Neutrophils accumulate in the injured tissue. Which mechanism most directly explains the immune system’s detection of this sterile danger signal?

options.A: IgE is for allergens/parasites, not DAMP detection.
options.B: Recognition of damage-associated molecular patterns by pattern recognition receptors on innate cells
options.C: BCR-driven clonal expansion is adaptive, delayed, and antigen-specific.
options.D: MHC II presentation of self would promote tolerance, not acute sterile inflammation.
options.E: C1q can bind debris, but PRR recognition of DAMPs is the initiating event here.

rationales.E: Recognition of damage-associated molecular patterns by pattern recognition receptors on innate cells Why this is right: Sterile injury releases DAMPs (e.g., HMGB1, ATP, uric acid) sensed by PRRs on macrophages and other innate cells, triggering inflammation and neutrophil recruitment even without microbes. This is the canonical danger-signal model linking tissue damage to an immediate innate response. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Neutrophils

questions.stem: A 41-year-old woman with poorly controlled diabetes presents with hypotension, fever, and confusion after a urinary tract infection. Blood cultures grow E. coli. Labs show high lactate and elevated IL-6 and TNF. Which proximal interaction best initiates the cytokine storm responsible for her septic shock?

options.A: Lipoteichoic acid is recognized by TLR2, not TLR4.
options.B: TLR4–MD2–CD14 recognition of lipopolysaccharide on Gram-negative bacteria
options.C: NOD2 senses muramyl dipeptide, not flagellin (TLR5).
options.D: RIG-I is for viral RNA, not bacterial LPS.
options.E: C3a is anaphylatoxin but not the initiating LPS sensor causing septic shock.

rationales.E: TLR4–MD2–CD14 recognition of lipopolysaccharide on Gram-negative bacteria Why this is right: Gram-negative sepsis features LPS recognition by the TLR4–MD2–CD14 complex on innate cells, triggering NF-κB and massive cytokine release (TNF, IL-6) that drive hypotension and organ dysfunction. E. coli bacteremia is the classic context. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A 30-year-old man suffers blunt chest trauma in a car crash. He has tachypnea and hypoxemia; CT shows pulmonary contusions without infection. BAL fluid reveals extracellular ATP and mitochondrial DNA. Which early cytokine pattern in alveolar macrophages best reflects a PRR-mediated response to these signals?

options.A: IL-4/IL-5 reflect Th2/allergic responses.
options.B: Elevated IL-1β and IL-18 following inflammasome activation
options.C: IL-12/IFN-γ is more NK/Th1–driven antimicrobial activation.
options.D: IL-10/TGF-β dominate resolution, not the immediate danger response.
options.E: Type I IFNs are hallmarks of viral nucleic acid sensing, not sterile trauma.

rationales.E: Elevated IL-1β and IL-18 following inflammasome activation Why this is right: DAMPs like extracellular ATP and mitochondrial DNA can activate inflammasome pathways, leading to caspase-1–mediated processing and release of IL-1β and IL-18. This pattern fits sterile lung injury with PRR sensing of danger signals. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Detection and Response to Danger Signals

questions.stem: A 72-year-old man undergoes open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. Within hours he develops systemic inflammation with fever and leukocytosis despite sterile technique. Plasma shows high levels of circulating mitochondrial formyl peptides. Which receptor-mediated event most plausibly links these molecules to neutrophil recruitment and degranulation?

options.A: There is no IgG to trigger FcγR in sterile release.
options.B: NLRs detect intracellular ligands, not extracellular gradients for chemotaxis.
options.C: FPR1 engagement on neutrophils causing chemotaxis and activation
options.D: TCR recognition is antigen-specific and delayed.
options.E: MAC deposition is terminal complement; not the direct formyl-peptide mechanism. Subtopic: Main Components of Innate and Adaptive Immune Systems

rationales.E: FPR1 engagement on neutrophils causing chemotaxis and activation Why this is right: Mitochondrial formylated peptides act as DAMPs that bind formyl peptide receptors (e.g., FPR1) on neutrophils, promoting chemotaxis and degranulation—key early events in sterile postoperative inflammation. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A 67-year-old woman with COPD presents with fever and productive cough. Gram stain shows Gram-negative rods. Before culture results, which immediate component of host defense most limits bacterial spread in her airways?

options.A: IgG is adaptive and requires prior class switching.
options.B: Naïve CD8 cells are not immediate airway defenders against extracellular bacteria.
options.C: Epithelial barrier with ciliary clearance and antimicrobial peptides
options.D: Somatic hypermutation is a B-cell process, not a direct defense mechanism.
options.E: Memory B cells require activation and time to produce antibody.

rationales.E: Epithelial barrier with ciliary clearance and antimicrobial peptides Why this is right: Innate components—physical barriers, mucociliary clearance, defensins—provide immediate protection in the airways before adaptive responses are mobilized. In COPD, these defenses are often impaired, predisposing to bacterial infection. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Antibody Function in Host Defense and Immunopathology

questions.stem: A 5-year-old girl with recurrent viral infections has normal neutrophil counts and immunoglobulin levels. NK cell cytotoxicity assays are markedly reduced. Which innate mechanism best explains early control of virally infected cells that is compromised in this patient?

options.A: Th1 activation is adaptive and indirect.
options.B: Detection of missing-self (low MHC I) and stress ligands with perforin/granzyme-mediated killing
options.C: Opsonophagocytosis is for extracellular microbes.
options.D: Complement can opsonize but is not primary for infected host cells.
options.E: NK receptors are germline-encoded; they do not undergo V(D)J recombination.

rationales.E: Detection of missing-self (low MHC I) and stress ligands with perforin/granzyme-mediated killing Why this is right: NK cells detect reduced MHC I and stress-induced ligands, then kill targets via perforin/granzyme. Defective NK function predisposes to severe viral infections during the window before robust adaptive CTL responses. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Innate Immune Cells

questions.stem: A 29-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks’ gestation asks how vaccinations “work with” versus “work against” her body. You explain that her innate immune system will initially sense adjuvants and antigens, and her adaptive system will create specificity and memory. Which cell type is the critical bridge that captures antigen in tissues and initiates adaptive immune responses in lymph nodes?

options.A: Dendritic cell
options.B: Neutrophils kill but do not prime naïve T cells.
options.C: Eosinophils target parasites and allergy.
options.D: Basophils contribute to allergic inflammation.
options.E: Mesangial cells are renal, not immune APCs.

rationales.E: Dendritic cell Why this is right: Dendritic cells are professional antigen-presenting cells that sense danger via PRRs, process antigens, migrate to lymph nodes, and prime naïve T cells—linking innate detection to adaptive specificity and memory, including vaccine responses. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Components of Innate and Adaptive Immune Systems

questions.stem: A 47-year-old man with asplenia after trauma is counseled about his infection risk. Which adaptive component is most crucial for defense against encapsulated extracellular bacteria in the bloodstream, particularly in asplenic patients?

options.A: Naïve T cells are not immediate bloodstream defenders.
options.B: Marginal zone B cell–derived IgM with complement fixation and opsonization
options.C: pDCs make IFN for antiviral defense, not anti-encapsulated bacteria.
options.D: CTLs kill infected nucleated cells, not RBCs.
options.E: Th17 aids mucosa, not intravascular clearance of encapsulated organisms. Subtopic: Comparison of Innate and Adaptive Immune Systems

rationales.E: Marginal zone B cell–derived IgM with complement fixation and opsonization Why this is right: The spleen’s marginal zone B cells rapidly produce IgM that activates complement and opsonizes encapsulated bacteria for phagocytosis. Asplenic patients lack this rapid T-independent humoral response, increasing risk for fulminant sepsis. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A 21-year-old college student receives her first dose of an inactivated influenza vaccine. Ten days later, she is exposed to influenza but remains asymptomatic. Which feature best explains her protection at this time point?

options.A: Describes innate sensing, not vaccine-induced specificity.
options.B: Memory B cells typically dominate upon re-exposure; 10 days after first dose is primary response.
options.C: Generation of antigen-specific receptors via somatic recombination enabling clonal selection
options.D: Defensins are innate and nonspecific.
options.E: NETs are more antibacterial and not the key protective feature here.

rationales.E: Generation of antigen-specific receptors via somatic recombination enabling clonal selection Why this is right: By ~10 days, adaptive immunity has generated antigen-specific B and T cells via V(D)J recombination, clonal expansion, and differentiation. This yields specific, effective responses (including early antibodies) that provide protection beyond innate immediacy. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: A 3-year-old girl presents with high fever 18 hours after onset of otitis media. Which attribute supports an innate rather than adaptive response at this early time?

options.A: Antigen presentation is required to activate naïve T cells (adaptive).
options.B: Slow kinetics describes adaptive responses.
options.C: Recognition of conserved microbial motifs by fixed receptors
options.D: SHM yields high-affinity antibodies (adaptive).
options.E: Memory is a hallmark of adaptive immunity.

rationales.E: Recognition of conserved microbial motifs by fixed receptors Why this is right: Innate immunity responds within hours via germline-encoded receptors (PRRs) that recognize conserved patterns (PAMPs), explaining rapid fever and inflammation at 18 hours. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Components of Innate and Adaptive Immune Systems

questions.stem: A 60-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B is evaluated for functional cure after antivirals. He asks why his body “didn’t wipe this virus out early.” Which feature of adaptive immunity is essential for sterilizing clearance but requires days to develop?

options.A: — Correct (selected).
options.B: Neutrophils are less relevant for intracellular viral control.
options.C: CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes with antigen-specific killing of infected hepatocytes
options.D: Type I IFNs are innate and nonspecific.
options.E: MAC targets bacteria; nucleated host cells resist MAC-mediated lysis.

rationales.E: CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes with antigen-specific killing of infected hepatocytes Why this is right: Clearance of intracellular viruses like HBV depends on adaptive, antigen-specific CTLs that require priming and expansion—explaining delayed onset compared with innate mechanisms. Effective CTL responses correlate with functional cure. Why the others are wrong:

questions.expl: A — CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes with antigen-specific killing of infected hepatocytes Why this is right: Clearance of intracellular viruses like HBV depends on adaptive, antigen-specific CTLs that require priming and expansion—explaining delayed onset compared with innate mechanisms. Effective CTL responses correlate with functional cure. Why the others are wrong: A. — Correct (selected). B. Neutrophils are less relevant for intracellular viral control. D. Type I IFNs are innate and nonspecific. E. MAC targets bacteria; nucleated host cells resist MAC-mediated lysis.
questions.subtopic: Neutrophils

questions.stem: A 7-year-old boy receives his second dose of a conjugate vaccine. Two days later, he has only mild arm soreness. Which immune feature most distinguishes this secondary response from his primary response months earlier?

options.A: Greater magnitude and faster kinetics due to pre-existing memory B and T cells
options.B: Complement may contribute but is not the distinguishing hallmark of secondary responses.
options.C: TLR2 sensing does not explain secondary kinetics/affinity.
options.D: A fixed Th2 skew is not universal and doesn’t explain improved speed/strength.
options.E: Affinity increases, not decreases, after memory responses.

rationales.E: Greater magnitude and faster kinetics due to pre-existing memory B and T cells Why this is right: Secondary responses are faster and stronger because memory lymphocytes expand rapidly and produce higher-affinity antibodies, often with class switching already established—distinguishing adaptive memory from primary responses. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Immune Response Subsidence

questions.stem: A 58-year-old woman with prior COVID-19 infection has robust rapid neutralizing antibody titers upon re-exposure 1 year later, despite waning circulating antibody at baseline. Which statement best explains this phenomenon?

options.A: Innate receptor repertoires are germline-encoded.
options.B: Central tolerance is irrelevant to viral memory.
options.C: Memory B cells persist and rapidly differentiate into plasma cells on re-exposure
options.D: Persistent replication is not required for memory recall.
options.E: Neutrophils do not undergo V(D)J recombination. Subtopic: Immune Response Subsidence Q: PD-1/PD-L1 expression on exhausted T cells contributes to chronic infection persistence. [Restored Pathology]

rationales.E: Memory B cells persist and rapidly differentiate into plasma cells on re-exposure Why this is right: Even when serum antibody wanes, memory B cells remain and quickly generate high-affinity antibody upon antigen re-encounter, exemplifying adaptive memory. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: B Cell and T Cell Receptors, and their Antigens
questions.subtopic: Overall Structure of B Cell Receptors (Antibody)

questions.stem: A 62-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis starts high-dose systemic glucocorticoids for a flare. Within days, her joint swelling improves and her CRP falls. Which mechanism best explains how the immune response is being forced into subsidence?

options.A: Steroids suppress DC function; they don’t enhance presentation.
options.B: Steroids suppress, not upregulate, NF-κB cytokines.
options.C: Increased production of IL-10 and TGF-β and lymphocyte apoptosis
options.D: Th17 expansion is proinflammatory.
options.E: Complement regulation is not the principal steroid effect.

rationales.E: Increased production of IL-10 and TGF-β and lymphocyte apoptosis Why this is right: Glucocorticoids promote anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-10, TGF-β), reduce proinflammatory mediators, and induce lymphocyte apoptosis—accelerating the normal resolution/subsidence phase of immune responses. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Immune Response Subsidence

questions.stem: A 38-year-old woman had a severe bacterial cellulitis that resolved after antibiotics. She is healthy at follow-up, but flow cytometry shows a small population of antigen-experienced CD4+ and CD8+ T cells with high Bcl-2 and rapid proliferative capacity on restimulation. Which coordinated processes allowed the immune response to subside while preserving protection against future infection?

options.A: Complete deletion would preclude memory.
options.B: Specificity does not “switch” from protein to carbohydrate.
options.C: Contraction via apoptosis of most effector cells with survival of long-lived memory cells
options.D: Efferocytosis promotes, not inhibits, resolution.
options.E: Permanent MHC downregulation would impair future responses. Topic: Basics of Innate Immunity I [No high-yield questions available] Subtopic: Mechanisms of Innate Immunity

rationales.E: Contraction via apoptosis of most effector cells with survival of long-lived memory cells Why this is right: Resolution entails contraction (apoptosis of effectors) while a subset differentiates into memory cells with enhanced survival (Bcl-2) and rapid recall. This balances subsidence with preparedness for re-exposure. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Immune Response Subsidence

questions.stem: A 27-year-old man presents 6 hours after a contaminated laceration to his forearm sustained while repairing a rusty fence. He reports increasing throbbing pain and swelling around the wound but no purulent drainage yet. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse 104/min, BP 118/72 mm Hg. Exam shows erythema with warmth and mild edema extending 2 cm beyond the wound margin. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with a left shift; CRP is mildly elevated. You explain that the earliest host events restricting bacterial spread began within hours at local postcapillary venules. Which mechanism best initiated the rapid influx of the first phagocytes to the site of injury?

options.A: Opsonic IgG requires prior class switching and time.
options.B: Endothelial E-selectin–mediated neutrophil rolling induced by IL-1/TNF
options.C: Clonal T-cell expansion takes days, not hours.
options.D: Macrophage classical activation depends on IFN-γ and develops later.
options.E: Complement helps opsonize, but leukocyte recruitment is initiated by cytokine-driven selectins.

rationales.E: Endothelial E-selectin–mediated neutrophil rolling induced by IL-1/TNF Why this is right: Tissue injury and microbes trigger resident cells and macrophages to release IL-1 and TNF, upregulating E-selectin on endothelium and promoting neutrophil rolling within hours. Subsequent chemokines and integrin activation drive firm adhesion and transmigration, explaining the very early neutrophil influx and rubor/calor. This is a core innate mechanism that precedes antigen-specific lymphocyte activation. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Antibody Function in Host Defense and Immunopathology

questions.stem: A 33-year-old pediatric nurse develops abrupt fever, myalgias, and sore throat during an influenza outbreak. Within 24 hours, her nasal epithelial cells upregulate numerous antiviral genes, and neighboring uninfected cells display resistance to viral replication. Which innate mechanism most directly induces this early “antiviral state”?

options.A: Inflammasomes drive IL-1β, not the antiviral gene program.
options.B: MBL targets microbes via complement, not intracellular antiviral genes.
options.C: NETs target extracellular bacteria/fungi.
options.D: NK killing helps, but the “antiviral state” refers to IFN-driven gene induction.
options.E: Type I interferon signaling from infected and plasmacytoid dendritic cells Correct: E

rationales.E: Type I interferon signaling from infected and plasmacytoid dendritic cells Why this is right: Viral nucleic acid sensing induces IFN-α/β, which upregulate antiviral effectors (e.g., PKR, RNase L) in infected and neighboring cells, limiting replication within hours. Plasmacytoid dendritic cells amplify this signal systemically. This paracrine/autocrine response precedes adaptive immunity. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Innate Immune Cells

questions.stem: A 54-year-old man with uncontrolled diabetes presents with rapidly progressive cellulitis and bacteremia due to β-hemolytic streptococci. Blood smear shows toxic granulation in neutrophils. Despite antibiotics, he develops microvascular thrombosis and tissue necrosis. Which neutrophil-dependent innate mechanism most directly traps and concentrates bactericidal factors in necrotic tissue?

options.A: Endocytosis is not the extracellular trap mechanism.
options.B: Phagocytosis is important but doesn’t explain extracellular trapping.
options.C: Eosinophils target parasites and allergy.
options.D: Extrusion of chromatin-based neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs)
options.E: Complement aids opsonization but doesn’t form extracellular chromatin nets.

rationales.E: Extrusion of chromatin-based neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) Why this is right: NETs immobilize microbes in a mesh of chromatin and granular proteins at sites of severe infection and tissue damage, concentrating antimicrobial effectors. This can contribute to local thrombosis and necrosis in overwhelming infections. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Neutrophils

questions.stem: A 70-year-old woman with COPD presents with acute exacerbation and bacterial pneumonia. Prior to antibiotic therapy, which innate mechanism most enhances phagocytosis of extracellular bacteria in her alveoli?

options.A: Requires prior adaptive priming and time to produce.
options.B: NK cells target altered self, not extracellular bacteria.
options.C: C3b deposition on microbial surfaces with complement receptor–mediated uptake
options.D: IgA is protective but is an adaptive product; immediate opsonization is complement-driven.
options.E: Cross-presentation primes CTLs, not immediate bacterial clearance. Subtopic: Innate Immune Cells

rationales.E: C3b deposition on microbial surfaces with complement receptor–mediated uptake Why this is right: Complement opsonization via C3b promotes efficient phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages through complement receptors, a key rapid innate defense against extracellular bacteria in the lung. This precedes robust adaptive antibody responses. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A 22-year-old man develops an acutely inflamed, painful wound 12 hours after a skateboarding accident. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). The wound is erythematous with serosanguinous exudate. Aspirate shows numerous cells with multilobed nuclei and azurophilic granules containing myeloperoxidase. Which cell population is providing the earliest bulk of antimicrobial activity at this time point?

options.A: Neutrophils
options.B: DCs prime T cells rather than dominate early killing.
options.C: Eosinophils target helminths/allergy, not acute wounds.
options.D: NK cells target altered self and viruses.
options.E: Basophils mediate allergy, not early pyogenic defense.

rationales.E: Neutrophils Why this is right: Neutrophils are first responders, arriving within hours to phagocytose and kill bacteria via oxidative burst and granule enzymes. Their morphologic features in the aspirate confirm their predominance early after injury. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A 38-year-old traveler presents with abdominal pain and eosinophilia after returning from rural Southeast Asia. Stool O&P shows large ova consistent with a helminth. Which innate effector cell and mechanism primarily mediate killing of this pathogen?

options.A: NETs target extracellular bacteria.
options.B: Macrophages are less effective vs large helminths.
options.C: Eosinophils with antibody-dependent cytotoxicity and major basic protein
options.D: NK cells target altered self, not parasites.
options.E: DCs initiate T-cell responses, not direct helminth killing.

rationales.E: Eosinophils with antibody-dependent cytotoxicity and major basic protein Why this is right: Helminths are too large for phagocytosis; eosinophils bind IgE/IgG–coated parasites via Fc receptors and degranulate (MBP, eosinophil cationic protein) to damage their surface. This is a classic innate–adaptive interface. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A 42-year-old woman develops fever and lymphopenia with elevated serum IFN-stimulated gene expression within 12 hours of a dengue exposure. Which innate cell type is the dominant early source of type I interferons in systemic viral infections?

options.A: Monocytes make cytokines but are not the major IFN-α/β source.
options.B: Neutrophils are not dominant interferon producers.
options.C: Kupffer cells are tissue macrophages with limited systemic IFN output.
options.D: cDCs produce IFN but pDCs are the principal early source.
options.E: Plasmacytoid dendritic cells Correct: E

rationales.E: Plasmacytoid dendritic cells Why this is right: Plasmacytoid DCs sense viral nucleic acids via endosomal TLRs and secrete large amounts of IFN-α/β early, driving systemic antiviral programs. Their output exceeds that of most other leukocytes in viremic states. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Other PRRs in the Innate Immune System

questions.stem: A 68-year-old man with Parkinson disease experiences delirium during pneumonia. CSF is normal. PET imaging highlights activated CNS-resident phagocytes around microinfarcts. Which innate immune cell population is primarily responsible for debris clearance within the brain parenchyma?

options.A: Alveolar macrophages reside in lungs.
options.B: Microglia
options.C: Langerhans cells are epidermal DCs.
options.D: Osteoclasts resorb bone, not neural debris.
options.E: Mast cells mediate allergy, not parenchymal phagocytosis.

rationales.E: Microglia Why this is right: Microglia are CNS-resident macrophage-lineage cells that clear debris and orchestrate neuroinflammation. Their activation around injury sites is a hallmark of innate responses in the brain. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: A 7-year-old girl has two episodes of herpes simplex encephalitis despite normal immunoglobulins and lymphocyte counts. Fibroblasts fail to produce type I interferon in response to synthetic double-stranded RNA in endosomes. Defect of which receptor pathway most likely explains her susceptibility?

options.A: TLR4 senses LPS (Gram-negatives).
options.B: TLR2 senses Gram-positive motifs.
options.C: TLR3 recognition of double-stranded RNA with IRF3 activation
options.D: Dectin-1 targets fungi.
options.E: NOD1 senses cytosolic peptidoglycan fragments, not dsRNA.

rationales.E: TLR3 recognition of double-stranded RNA with IRF3 activation Why this is right: TLR3 senses dsRNA in endosomes to induce type I interferons crucial for antiviral defense in the CNS; genetic defects predispose to HSV encephalitis with otherwise intact adaptive immunity. The functional assay mirrors TLR3 signaling. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Detection and Response to Danger Signals

questions.stem: A 45-year-old man presents in septic shock with Gram-negative bacteremia. Monocytes strongly activate NF-κB on exposure to patient plasma. Which receptor–ligand interaction most likely initiates this response?

options.A: TLR4–MD2–CD14 binding to lipopolysaccharide lipid A
options.B: TLR2 targets Gram-positive motifs.
options.C: TLR5 senses flagellin at the surface/endosome, not cytosol.
options.D: TLR9 recognizes unmethylated CpG DNA.
options.E: NLRP3 activates IL-1β, but LPS recognition is upstream via TLR4.

rationales.E: TLR4–MD2–CD14 binding to lipopolysaccharide lipid A Why this is right: LPS from Gram-negative bacteria binds the TLR4–MD2–CD14 complex to trigger NF-κB and proinflammatory cytokines central to septic shock. Lipid A is the toxic moiety. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A 64-year-old man with urosepsis develops hypotension, warm extremities, and rising lactate. He has fevers and marked anorexia with weight loss over several days. Which cytokine is most centrally responsible for the hemodynamic collapse and cachexia associated with severe sepsis?

options.A: IL-1 causes fever but is less central to shock.
options.B: IL-12 promotes Th1/NK IFN-γ, not shock.
options.C: IFN-α is antiviral.
options.D: TNF-α
options.E: IL-10 is anti-inflammatory.

rationales.E: TNF-α Why this is right: TNF-α drives vasodilation, increased permeability, and myocardial depression in septic shock, and mediates cachexia through catabolic signaling. It synergizes with IL-1/IL-6 but is the principal culprit in shock physiology. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A 31-year-old woman has a painful, erythematous leg wound with purulent drainage. Tissue cytokine analysis shows high levels of a chemokine that binds CXCR1/2 on neutrophils. Which mediator most directly promotes neutrophil chemotaxis to this site?

options.A: IL-1 causes fever/endothelial activation.
options.B: IL-8 (CXCL8)
options.C: IL-6 drives acute-phase responses.
options.D: IFN-γ activates macrophages rather than chemotaxing neutrophils.
options.E: IL-2 expands T cells.

rationales.E: IL-8 (CXCL8) Why this is right: IL-8 is the key chemokine for neutrophil chemotaxis and activation via CXCR1/2, explaining the robust neutrophil influx in purulent bacterial infection. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A 49-year-old man with acute hepatitis C has flu-like symptoms and increased expression of Mx proteins and oligoadenylate synthetase in hepatocytes. Which cytokines are primarily responsible for inducing this antiviral gene program?

options.A: IL-1 and IL-6
options.B: TNF-α and IL-1
options.C: IFN-α and IFN-β
options.D: IFN-γ activates macrophages; IL-12 drives Th1.
options.E: IL-10/TGF-β are regulatory.

rationales.E: IFN-α and IFN-β Why this is right: Type I interferons induce a suite of antiviral effectors (e.g., Mx, OAS, PKR) that inhibit viral replication in infected and neighboring cells. Why the others are wrong: A/B. IL-1/IL-6 contribute to fever/acute-phase, not antiviral genes.

questions.stem: A 70-year-old woman with giant cell arteritis is treated with an IL-6 receptor antagonist and notes rapid improvement in fevers and normalization of CRP. Which cytokine is being blocked to produce these effects?

options.A: IL-1β
options.B: TNF-α
options.C: IFN-γ is not the main acute-phase driver.
options.D: IL-18 promotes IFN-γ but is not primary for CRP. Subtopic: Innate Immune Receptors Q: Which receptor family (besides TLRs) recognizes fungal β-glucans on Candida? [HIGH YIELD] Q: Scavenger receptors on macrophages are important for binding and clearing what type of molecules? [HIGH YIELD] Q: Which Toll-like receptor recognizes lipopolysaccharide (LPS) on Gram-negative bacteria? [HIGH YIELD] Q: MyD88 deficiency leads to impaired signaling of most TLRs. Which infections are patients especially prone to? [HIGH YIELD] Subtopic: Innate Immune Cytokines Q: Which cytokine is the main mediator of septic shock? [HIGH YIELD] Q: IL-12 drives differentiation of which T helper subset? [HIGH YIELD] Q: Type I interferons induce an antiviral state in neighboring cells. Which two interferons are type I? [HIGH YIELD] Subtopic: The Complement System Q: Deficiency of terminal complement components predisposes to recurrent Neisseria infections. [Restored Pathology]
options.E: IL-6 Correct: E

rationales.E: IL-6 Why this is right: IL-6 drives hepatic acute-phase protein synthesis (e.g., CRP) and contributes to fever; blockade rapidly reduces CRP and systemic symptoms in inflammatory diseases. Why the others are wrong: A/B. Blocking IL-1 or TNF can reduce fever but would not specifically normalize CRP as directly.

questions.stem: A 12-year-old girl has recurrent sinus infections and otitis media. Total hemolytic complement assay (CH50) is undetectable, but alternative pathway hemolytic activity (AH50) is normal. Which complement component deficiency best explains these findings?

options.A: Properdin stabilizes the alternative pathway; AH50 would be low.
options.B: C2
options.C: Factor D is required for the alternative pathway; AH50 would be low. D/E. C3 or C5 defects lower both CH50 and AH50.
options.D: C3
options.E: C5 Correct: B

rationales.E: C2 Why this is right: Low CH50 with normal AH50 indicates a classical pathway defect (C1, C2, or C4). C2 deficiency is the most common classical component deficiency and fits the preserved alternative pathway function. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: The Complement System

questions.stem: A 19-year-old woman has recurrent, nonpruritic facial and laryngeal swelling after dental work and stress. C4 is persistently low between attacks; C1q is normal. Which deficiency is most likely?

options.A: Would not explain isolated low C4 with classic HAE features.
options.B: DAF deficiency causes hemolysis (PNH), not isolated angioedema.
options.C: C1 esterase inhibitor
options.D: Factor H defects affect the alternative pathway regulation.
options.E: C9 deficiency predisposes to Neisseria, not angioedema.

rationales.E: C1 esterase inhibitor Why this is right: Hereditary angioedema from C1-INH deficiency features low C4 with normal C1q and recurrent, nonurticarial angioedema, often triggered by trauma or stress due to unchecked kallikrein–bradykinin activation. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Relationship Between Cytokine Profiles Produced by Th Cells and ILCs

questions.stem: A 7-year-old boy has two episodes of meningococcemia. CH50 is low; AH50 is also low. Which specific complement defect is most consistent with his susceptibility?

options.A: C1q
options.B: C2
options.C: C4
options.D: C3 deficiency increases pyogenic infections broadly, not specifically Neisseria.
options.E: — Correct.

rationales.E: Terminal complement (C5–C9) deficiency Why this is right: Deficiency of the membrane attack complex predisposes to recurrent Neisseria infections because MAC-mediated lysis is critical for these bacteria. Both CH50 and AH50 are reduced since the terminal pathway is shared. Why the others are wrong: A–C. Classical pathway defects often spare AH50.

questions.subtopic: The Complement System

questions.stem: A 35-year-old man has episodic dark urine, abdominal pain, and hepatic vein thrombosis. Flow cytometry shows absence of CD55 (DAF) and CD59 on erythrocytes. Which mechanism best explains his hemolysis?

options.A: Autoantibodies are not the driver here.
options.B: Properdin excess is not the core lesion.
options.C: C1-INH excess would not cause hemolysis.
options.D: Uncontrolled complement MAC formation on RBCs due to loss of GPI-anchored regulators
options.E: The issue is excessive, not absent, complement attack on RBCs.

rationales.E: Uncontrolled complement MAC formation on RBCs due to loss of GPI-anchored regulators Why this is right: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria results from PIGA mutations causing loss of GPI-anchored CD55/CD59, rendering RBCs susceptible to complement-mediated lysis, especially intravascular by MAC. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: A 40-year-old man with recurrent pyelonephritis has normal C3 and C4 levels. Functional testing shows robust alternative pathway activity that depends on stabilization of the C3 convertase (C3bBb). Which protein physiologically stabilizes this convertase on microbial surfaces?

options.A: Properdin
options.B: Factor I cleaves C3b (inactivating).
options.C: Factor H accelerates decay of the convertase and co-factors Factor I.
options.D: C1q initiates the classical pathway.
options.E: MASP-2 functions in the lectin pathway. Topic: Basics of Innate Immunity II [No high-yield questions available] Subtopic: The TLR System

rationales.E: Properdin Why this is right: Properdin (factor P) stabilizes the alternative pathway C3 convertase (C3bBb), prolonging its activity and enhancing opsonization. This is a unique positive regulator of complement. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: The IL-12, IFN-γ Pathway

questions.stem: In a research unit, dermal fibroblasts from a 4-year-old boy with recurrent severe viral encephalitis are stimulated with poly(I:C), a synthetic double-stranded RNA. Cells fail to produce IFN-β unless transfected with cytosolic RNA, and IFN-β production is restored when the medium is acidified to enhance endosomal function. Western blot shows intact MyD88 expression. His parents ask how his cells “sense” viral material to trigger interferon. Which receptor-pathway best explains the missing signal?

options.A: TLR2 detects Gram-positive motifs, not viral dsRNA.
options.B: TLR9 senses CpG DNA, not dsRNA.
options.C: TLR3 recognition of dsRNA in endosomes with TRIF–IRF3 activation
options.D: NOD2 detects cytosolic peptidoglycan fragments.
options.E: RIG-I is cytosolic; the defect resolves with endosomal rescue.

rationales.E: TLR3 recognition of dsRNA in endosomes with TRIF–IRF3 activation Why this is right: Endosomal TLR3 senses dsRNA and signals via TRIF to activate IRF3, inducing type I interferons. Dependence on endosomal acidification and preserved MyD88 point to a TRIF-dependent TLR (TLR3). Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: The IL-12, IFN-γ Pathway

questions.stem: A 62-year-old man develops septic shock 8 hours after perforated diverticulitis. Plasma shows high TNF and IL-6. A pharmacology team is testing inhibitors that block the very first extracellular recognition event that triggers this cytokine storm. Which interaction should their drug disrupt?

options.A: TLR4–MD2–CD14 binding of lipid A on Gram-negative LPS
options.B: TLR2 recognizes Gram-positive motifs.
options.C: TLR5 senses flagellin, not the key septic trigger here.
options.D: TLR7 is antiviral.
options.E: NLRP3 acts downstream to mature IL-1β, not the initial LPS sensor.

rationales.E: TLR4–MD2–CD14 binding of lipid A on Gram-negative LPS Why this is right: Early Gram-negative sepsis is driven by LPS engaging TLR4 with MD2 and CD14, initiating NF-κB–mediated cytokines. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A 70-year-old postsurgical patient develops hypotension and fever. Blood cultures grow Streptococcus pyogenes. Monocytes from this patient produce TNF when exposed to purified lipoteichoic acid and peptidoglycan. Which receptor pair initiates this response?

options.A: TLR4 senses LPS (Gram-negative).
options.B: TLR2/TLR6 heterodimer
options.C: TLR3 detects dsRNA.
options.D: TLR7 detects ssRNA.
options.E: Dectin-1 recognizes fungal β-glucan.

rationales.E: TLR2/TLR6 heterodimer Why this is right: TLR2 (often with TLR6) recognizes Gram-positive lipoteichoic acid/peptidoglycan, leading to NF-κB activation. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Detection and Response to Danger Signals

questions.stem: A 31-year-old pregnant woman has influenza-like illness but limited viremia. Her plasmacytoid dendritic cells show robust type I interferon production after exposure to synthetic ssRNA in endosomes. Which receptor pathway most directly accounts for this antiviral output?

options.A: CpG DNA is not the ligand provided.
options.B: RIG-I is cytosolic, not endosomal.
options.C: TLR4 signals bacterial LPS.
options.D: TLR7–MyD88 sensing ssRNA in endosomes
options.E: NOD2 senses bacterial cell wall fragments. Subtopic: The Inflammasome and Autoinflammatory Diseases

rationales.E: TLR7–MyD88 sensing ssRNA in endosomes Why this is right: pDCs rely on endosomal TLR7 (and TLR9) with MyD88 to produce large amounts of IFN-α in response to viral ssRNA. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Treg cells (Regulatory T cells)

questions.stem: A 14-year-old boy has recurrent fevers, serositis, and migratory arthritis since early childhood, often after minor stress. WBC is elevated during attacks; cultures are negative. A maternal uncle has similar symptoms. Colchicine prevents flares. Which defect best explains this autoinflammatory syndrome?

options.A: CAPS presents with cold-induced urticaria and hearing loss.
options.B: C1-INH deficiency causes angioedema, not serositis/arthritis.
options.C: ANCA vasculitis shows capillaritis, not periodic sterile fevers.
options.D: Pyrin inflammasome dysregulation from MEFV mutation
options.E: dsDNA autoimmunity indicates SLE.

rationales.E: Pyrin inflammasome dysregulation from MEFV mutation Why this is right: Familial Mediterranean fever is due to MEFV mutations affecting pyrin, leading to IL-1–mediated serosal inflammation and colchicine responsiveness. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: The Inflammasome and Autoinflammatory Diseases

questions.stem: A 58-year-old man with severe Gram-negative sepsis develops high fevers and circulating IL-1β. Monocyte death assays show rapid, lytic cell death with pore formation and IL-1β release. Which molecular event is central to this death pathway?

options.A: Apaf-1 activation and caspase-9–mediated apoptosis
options.B: Necroptosis is caspase-independent.
options.C: Caspase-1 cleavage of gasdermin D forming membrane pores (pyroptosis)
options.D: Bax/Bak–mediated mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization
options.E: Autophagy is a homeostatic process, not IL-1β release.

rationales.E: Caspase-1 cleavage of gasdermin D forming membrane pores (pyroptosis) Why this is right: Inflammasome-activated caspase-1 cleaves gasdermin D to create pores, causing pyroptotic lysis and IL-1β release. Why the others are wrong: A/D. These are apoptotic pathways (non-lytic, IL-1β-poor).

questions.stem: A laboratory identifies a patient whose monocytes produce normal pro–IL-1β after LPS but cannot secrete mature IL-1β when the NLRP3 inflammasome is activated with ATP. Caspase-1 protein is present but doesn’t bind the sensor. Which adaptor is most likely defective?

options.A: TRIF
options.B: ASC (PYCARD)
options.C: IRAK4
options.D: MAVS
options.E: STING Correct: B

rationales.E: ASC (PYCARD) Why this is right: ASC bridges NLR sensors to caspase-1 via its PYD and CARD domains; without ASC, pro–IL-1β cannot be processed. Why the others are wrong: A/C. TRIF/IRAK4 are TLR adaptors, not inflammasome scaffolds. D/E. MAVS and STING are RNA/DNA sensing adaptors, not the IL-1β inflammasome adaptor. Subtopic: Other PRRs in the Innate Immune System

questions.stem: A 55-year-old man with Candida albicans fungemia has macrophages that internalize yeasts efficiently even without opsonins. Which receptor most directly mediates recognition and endocytosis of mannose-rich fungal glycans on macrophages?

options.A: Mannose receptor (CD206)
options.B: TLR2 triggers cytokines, not primary uptake.
options.C: SR-A binds modified self and some microbes, less specific for mannans. D/E. Require IgG or C3b opsonins.
options.D: FcγRIII (CD16)
options.E: Complement receptor 3 (CD11b/CD18) Correct: A

rationales.E: Mannose receptor (CD206) Why this is right: CD206 binds terminal mannose/fucose residues on microbes and promotes endocytosis independent of opsonins. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A neonate has delayed separation of the umbilical cord, omphalitis, recurrent skin infections without pus, and marked neutrophilia. Flow cytometry shows absent CD18 on neutrophils. Which step in recruitment is primarily defective?

options.A: Rolling uses selectins, intact here. C/D/E. Occur after firm adhesion or are downstream functions.
options.B: Firm adhesion via β2 integrins (CD18) binding ICAM-1
options.C: Chemotaxis along C5a and IL-8 gradients
options.D: Diapedesis through PECAM-1 at endothelial junctions
options.E: Opsonophagocytosis via Fcγ receptors Correct: B

rationales.E: Firm adhesion via β2 integrins (CD18) binding ICAM-1 Why this is right: LAD-1 (CD18 deficiency) prevents integrin-mediated firm adhesion, causing poor pus formation and leukocytosis. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Neutrophils

questions.stem: A 7-year-old boy has recurrent pyogenic infections, oculocutaneous albinism, peripheral neuropathy, and giant azurophilic granules in neutrophils on smear. Which defect underlies his disease?

options.A: NADPH oxidase mutation impairing superoxide production
options.B: Myeloperoxidase deficiency impairing HOCl formation
options.C: Deficiency of Sialyl-Lewis^x impairing rolling
options.D: Deficiency of CD18 impairing firm adhesion
options.E: LYST mutation causing defective lysosomal trafficking and phagolysosome fusion Correct: E

rationales.E: LYST mutation causing defective lysosomal trafficking and phagolysosome fusion Why this is right: Chediak–Higashi syndrome features LYST defects → giant granules, albinism, neuropathy, and recurrent infections. Why the others are wrong: A/B. Oxidative defects lack albinism and giant granules. C/D. Adhesion defects present without giant granules or albinism.

questions.subtopic: Neutrophils

questions.stem: A 62-year-old woman receiving cytotoxic chemotherapy develops febrile neutropenia (ANC 200/µL). She is started on broad-spectrum antibiotics and a hematopoietic growth factor that accelerates neutrophil recovery. Which mechanism best describes this drug’s action?

options.A: G-CSF binding to myeloid progenitors to expand and mobilize neutrophils
options.B: IL-2 stimulation of naïve T-cell clonal expansion
options.C: IFN-γ activation of macrophage microbicidal pathways
options.D: Erythropoietin activation of erythroid precursors
options.E: GM-CSF supports myeloid growth; it doesn’t inhibit granulopoiesis.

rationales.E: G-CSF binding to myeloid progenitors to expand and mobilize neutrophils Why this is right: G-CSF enhances neutrophil production and egress, shortening neutropenia duration. Why the others are wrong: B/C/D. Target non-neutrophil lineages/functions.

questions.subtopic: Other PRRs in the Innate Immune System

questions.stem: A 48-year-old man with cellulitis shows leukocytosis. Early recruitment of neutrophils to postcapillary venules is studied in vivo. Which molecular interaction mediates initial rolling on activated endothelium?

options.A: ICAM-1 binding to LFA-1 (CD11a/CD18)
options.B: VCAM-1 binding to VLA-4
options.C: E-selectin on endothelium binding Sialyl-Lewis^x on neutrophils
options.D: Chemokine signaling activates integrins after rolling.
options.E: PECAM-1 functions at diapedesis.

rationales.E: E-selectin on endothelium binding Sialyl-Lewis^x on neutrophils Why this is right: Selectin–SLe^x interactions mediate rolling; integrins mediate firm adhesion later. Why the others are wrong: A/B. Firm adhesion steps, not rolling.

questions.subtopic: Neutrophils

questions.stem: A 35-year-old man has recurrent mucocutaneous Candida infections. Dihydrorhodamine testing shows a normal oxidative burst. However, neutrophil granules fail to generate microbicidal hypochlorous acid. Which enzyme is deficient?

options.A: Would impair DHR test. B/C/E. Not the primary HOCl-generating enzyme in neutrophil granules. Subtopic: Neutrophils Q: Which enzyme defect causes chronic granulomatous disease (CGD)? [HIGH YIELD] Q: Which cytokines (from macrophages) are key for neutrophil recruitment? [HIGH YIELD] Subtopic: The IL-12, IFN-γ Pathway
options.B: Superoxide dismutase
options.C: Catalase
options.D: Myeloperoxidase
options.E: Inducible nitric oxide synthase Correct: D

rationales.E: Myeloperoxidase Why this is right: MPO converts H2O2 and Cl− into HOCl in azurophilic granules; deficiency predisposes to Candida with normal oxidase testing. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Lytic granules

questions.stem: A 10-month-old boy develops disseminated BCG following routine vaccination. PBMCs produce little IFN-γ when stimulated with killed mycobacteria. Genetic testing shows an IL-12 receptor β1 mutation. Which therapy would most directly improve macrophage activation in this child?

options.A: Anti–IL-6 receptor antibody
options.B: Steroids suppress Th1 responses.
options.C: TNF-α inhibitor
options.D: Antibiotics don’t fix the immunologic defect.
options.E: Exogenous IFN-γ administration Correct: E

rationales.E: Exogenous IFN-γ administration Why this is right: IL-12R deficiency impairs Th1/NK IFN-γ production; providing IFN-γ bypasses the upstream defect and improves mycobacterial control. Why the others are wrong: A/C. Blocking cytokines worsens intracellular pathogen control.

questions.subtopic: The IL-12, IFN-γ Pathway

questions.stem: A 58-year-old woman on a JAK inhibitor for rheumatoid arthritis develops reactivation of latent tuberculosis. In vitro, her monocytes respond to IFN-γ by upregulating IFN-γ receptor but fail to induce IRF1 target genes. Which signaling step is most directly blocked by her medication?

options.A: IL-12 uses JAK2/TYK2 and STAT4, not the IFN-γ step asked. B/D/E. These are other pathways not specific to IFN-γ–JAK–STAT1.
options.B: MyD88-dependent TLR signaling
options.C: STAT1 phosphorylation downstream of IFN-γ receptor–associated JAKs
options.D: NF-κB p65 nuclear translocation in macrophages
options.E: SMAD2/3 phosphorylation downstream of TGF-β Correct: C

rationales.E: STAT1 phosphorylation downstream of IFN-γ receptor–associated JAKs Why this is right: IFN-γ signals through JAK1/JAK2 to phosphorylate STAT1; JAK inhibition prevents STAT1 activation and Th1-mediated control of TB. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: The IL-12, IFN-γ Pathway

questions.stem: A 23-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, and cavitary pulmonary lesions from Mycobacterium kansasii. CD4+ T cells produce robust IFN-γ after antigen stimulation. Which downstream effect in macrophages is critical for intracellular killing of this organism?

options.A: Upregulation of IL-4/IL-13 to enhance alternative activation
options.B: Killing requires NO/ROS, not suppression.
options.C: Mycobacteria inhibit fusion; IFN-γ counters this.
options.D: IFN-γ–driven classical activation with enhanced ROS and NO generation
options.E: Increased IL-10 production to restrain inflammation Correct: D

rationales.E: IFN-γ–driven classical activation with enhanced ROS and NO generation Why this is right: IFN-γ activates macrophage microbicidal pathways (ROS, NO) and promotes phagolysosome maturation to kill intracellular mycobacteria. Why the others are wrong: A/E. Drive regulatory/alternative programs, not killing.

questions.stem: Whole-exome sequencing in a toddler with recurrent Salmonella and mycobacterial infections reveals a mutation in IL12B. Which molecular consequence best explains his phenotype?

options.A: Loss of IFN-γ receptor expression on macrophages
options.B: Deficiency of the p40 subunit shared by IL-12 and IL-23
options.C: Absence of the p35 subunit specific to IL-12 only
options.D: Overproduction of IL-18 driving excessive Th1 activation
options.E: Gain-of-function STAT1 mutation causing hyper-IFN signaling Correct: B

rationales.E: Deficiency of the p40 subunit shared by IL-12 and IL-23 Why this is right: IL12B encodes the p40 subunit used by IL-12 (p35/p40) and IL-23 (p19/p40); deficiency impairs Th1 and some Th17 functions, predisposing to intracellular infections. Why the others are wrong: A/C. Do not capture the shared p40 biology; p35 loss spares IL-23. D/E. Would not cause this susceptibility pattern.

questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A child with severe, recurrent disseminated mycobacterial disease fails to improve with exogenous IFN-γ therapy. Monocyte testing shows normal IL-12–induced IFN-γ from T cells, but macrophages do not upregulate iNOS or HLA-DR after IFN-γ stimulation. Which defect best explains these findings?

options.A: Loss-of-function mutation in IFN-γ receptor (IFNGR1) preventing JAK-STAT1 signaling
options.B: Would reduce IFN-γ production, not response. C/D/E. Don’t specifically abolish macrophage responses to IFN-γ. Topic: Overview of the Adaptive Immune System [No high-yield questions available] Subtopic: Lymphocyte Development
options.C: Defect in TLR4 recognition of LPS reducing IL-12 production
options.D: NOD2 loss-of-function impairing muramyl dipeptide sensing
options.E: TRIF deficiency preventing TLR3 signaling Correct: A

rationales.E: Loss-of-function mutation in IFN-γ receptor (IFNGR1) preventing JAK-STAT1 signaling Why this is right: Normal IFN-γ production but absent macrophage response to IFN-γ indicates an IFN-γ receptor pathway defect; exogenous IFN-γ is ineffective. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: The IL-12, IFN-γ Pathway

questions.stem: A 3-month-old boy is evaluated for severe oral thrush, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive. He has had two hospitalizations for pneumonia. Physical exam reveals absent tonsillar tissue and small lymph nodes. Chest radiograph shows a normal-sized cardiac silhouette and a thymic shadow that is difficult to appreciate. Flow cytometry demonstrates profoundly decreased CD3+ T cells and CD19+ B cells, with normal NK cell numbers. Serum immunoglobulins are undetectable. A defect in which process best explains this presentation?

options.A: ADA deficiency usually reduces T, B, and NK cells.
options.B: γc (IL2RG) defects spare B-cell numbers (T−B+NK−).
options.C: V(D)J recombination of antigen receptor genes by RAG1/2 endonucleases
options.D: TAP defects impair CD8 selection but do not eliminate B cells.
options.E: BTK defects block B-cell maturation but T cells are preserved.

rationales.E: V(D)J recombination of antigen receptor genes by RAG1/2 endonucleases Why this is right: Combined absence of mature T and B cells with intact NK cells and agammaglobulinemia is classic for RAG1/2 defects preventing V(D)J recombination. Without rearranged TCR and BCR genes, lymphocyte development stalls at early stages in thymus and marrow. This causes severe, early-onset infections and failure to thrive. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A 7-year-old boy’s bone marrow shows numerous cells expressing μ heavy chains in the cytoplasm and surrogate light chains (VpreB/λ5) on the surface. Signaling through this complex halts further rearrangement of the second heavy-chain allele. Which developmental checkpoint is being enforced?

options.A: Occurs later at the immature B-cell stage. B/E. Occur after antigen encounter in germinal centers.
options.B: Class-switch recombination to downstream constant regions
options.C: Editing targets light chains, not heavy chains.
options.D: Allelic exclusion of the immunoglobulin heavy-chain locus
options.E: Somatic hypermutation within germinal centers Correct: D

rationales.E: Allelic exclusion of the immunoglobulin heavy-chain locus Why this is right: Pre-BCR signaling (μ heavy chain + surrogate light chain with Igα/Igβ) confirms a productive heavy-chain rearrangement and enforces allelic exclusion, preventing additional heavy-chain rearrangements. This maintains monospecificity. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Treg cells (Regulatory T cells)

questions.stem: A 4-year-old boy has recurrent viral and opportunistic infections. Flow cytometry shows normal numbers of CD4 and markedly reduced CD8 T cells. TCRs are present on both subsets, but TCR signaling is defective in CD8 lineage; responses improve with anti-CD3 crosslinking at very high doses. Which signaling molecule is most likely mutated?

options.A: ZAP-70
options.B: Syk is the BCR analog; TCR relies on ZAP-70.
options.C: Lck is proximal but its complete loss affects both CD4 and CD8 more globally.
options.D: CD21 is a B-cell coreceptor (EBV receptor).
options.E: BTK affects BCR signaling, not TCR.

rationales.E: ZAP-70 Why this is right: ZAP-70 binds phosphorylated ITAMs of the CD3 ζ chain and is essential for TCR signaling and positive selection. Loss characteristically produces very low CD8 cells with nonfunctional CD4 cells. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A researcher compares antigen recognition by B cells and T cells from the same donor. Which statement best distinguishes their receptors’ recognition properties?

options.A: Both BCR and TCR recognize intact native proteins on APCs
options.B: Both require antigen processing and presentation by MHC molecules
options.C: BCR binds native conformational or linear epitopes; TCR recognizes processed peptide bound to MHC
options.D: Affinity maturation is a BCR phenomenon; TCR affinity does not somatically mutate.
options.E: β2-microglobulin is a component of MHC I, not the BCR.

rationales.E: BCR binds native conformational or linear epitopes; TCR recognizes processed peptide bound to MHC Why this is right: BCR (membrane Ig) can bind native antigen directly; TCR is MHC-restricted and recognizes peptides presented by APCs. Which structural part of the antibody most directly mediates the effector interactions that promote phagocytosis and complement activation in this setting?

options.C: The hinge confers flexibility but not direct receptor/complement binding.
options.D: Fc portion of the heavy-chain constant region

options.B: The J chain is in IgM/IgA polymers, not IgG.
options.C: CH3 domains of heavy chains
options.D: Carbohydrate moieties in CH2 domains
options.E: Hinge region between CH1 and CH2 segments Correct: E

options.C: Dimeric IgA J chain engagement of FcαRI on syncytiotrophoblasts
options.D: IgM doesn’t cross the placenta.

options.B: Allotype

options.D: Isotype

options.E: Binding to FcRn on epithelial cells Correct: D

options.A: IgE-mediated eosinophil degranulation
options.B: IgA neutralization across mucosa
options.C: IgD signaling on naïve B cells
options.D: IgG and C3b opsonization enabling Fcγ/complement receptor–mediated phagocytosis
options.E: Superantigen activation of T cells Correct: D

rationales.E: IgG and C3b opsonization enabling Fcγ/complement receptor–mediated phagocytosis Why this is right: Encapsulated bacteria are cleared by opsonins; IgG binds Fcγ receptors and C3b binds complement receptors on phagocytes, compensating for lack of splenic filtration. options.E: Cross the placenta to protect the fetus Correct: D

options.E: IgG binding to FcγRIIA (CD32A) on platelets Correct: E

options.E: FcαRI Correct: A

options.C: Not the dominant mechanism.

options.E: Cross-presentation by specialized dendritic cells Correct: E

rationales.E: Cross-presentation by specialized dendritic cells Why this is right: Certain DCs route exogenous antigens into the class I pathway to prime naïve CD8 T cells. Why the others are wrong: A/B. Class II steps.

questions.subtopic: MHC Class I and Class II Molecules

questions.stem: A viral immune-evasion protein prevents peptide transport into the ER. Infected cells show low class I on the surface and are killed by NK cells. Which statement best explains the dual effect?

options.A: Blocked class II loading prevents Th1 help
options.B: Enhanced HLA-DM activity triggers apoptosis
options.C: Increased β2-microglobulin promotes NK activation
options.D: Loss of class I presentation impairs CD8 recognition and removes inhibitory NK signals (“missing self”)
options.E: Increased TAP activity depletes peptides Correct: D

rationales.E: Loss of class I presentation impairs CD8 recognition and removes inhibitory NK signals (“missing self”) Why this is right: Blocking TAP lowers class I, evading CTLs but triggering NK killing due to missing inhibitory ligands. Why the others are wrong: A/B/C/E. Do not explain the observed pattern.

questions.subtopic: Innate Immune Cells

questions.stem: Conjugate vaccines link bacterial polysaccharide to a protein carrier. How do B cells specific for the polysaccharide receive T-cell help?

options.A: By presenting the intact polysaccharide on class I to CD8 cells
options.B: By internalizing the conjugate, presenting carrier peptides on class II to Tfh cells, then class-switching against the polysaccharide
options.C: By secreting IL-4 to self-help
options.D: By cross-presenting carrier peptides on class I
options.E: By engaging NK cells via ADCC Correct: B

rationales.E: By internalizing the conjugate, presenting carrier peptides on class II to Tfh cells, then class-switching against the polysaccharide Why this is right: BCR-mediated uptake enables MHC II presentation of carrier peptides, unlocking T-dependent help for anti-polysaccharide responses. Why the others are wrong: A/D. Incorrect pathways. C/E. Not the mechanism of T-dependent help.

questions.subtopic: Treg cells (Regulatory T cells)

questions.stem: After in vivo DC–tumor cell contact, native tumor peptide–MHC I complexes are detected on bystander DCs that never phagocytosed tumor proteins. Which phenomenon explains this?

options.A: Cross-presentation
options.B: Cross-priming
options.C: Epitope spreading
options.D: Immunodominance
options.E: Cross-dressing (transfer of intact peptide–MHC complexes between cells) Correct: E

rationales.E: Cross-dressing (transfer of intact peptide–MHC complexes between cells) Why this is right: Cross-dressing moves preformed pMHC complexes to recipient APCs, distinct from processing exogenous protein. Why the others are wrong: A/B. Require processing; here intact complexes were transferred. C/D. Different concepts.

questions.stem: Researchers culture APCs with a weak base that neutralizes endosomal pH. CD4+ T-cell activation falls, but CD8+ responses to cytosolic viral proteins remain intact. Which step was inhibited?

options.A: Endosomal proteolysis and peptide loading onto class II (requires acidification)
options.B: Proteasome generation of peptides for class I
options.C: TAP-mediated peptide import
options.D: β2-microglobulin association with class I
options.E: Not an antigen-processing step. Subtopic: Types of Transplant Rejection

rationales.E: Endosomal proteolysis and peptide loading onto class II (requires acidification) Why this is right: Class II processing depends on acidic endosomes; neutralization blocks peptide generation/loading for CD4 responses. Why the others are wrong: B–D. Class I pathway steps; unaffected here.

questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: Minutes after a kidney is reperfused, the recipient develops cyanotic mottling of the graft and no urine output. Biopsy shows widespread fibrin thrombi in glomerular capillaries and neutrophil margination. Which mechanism best explains this event?

options.A: Delayed-type hypersensitivity to minor antigens
options.B: Direct allorecognition by recipient T cells
options.C: Describes chronic rejection.
options.D: Preformed recipient IgG against donor antigens causing complement-mediated thrombosis (hyperacute rejection)
options.E: GVHD occurs in stem-cell transplants.

rationales.E: Preformed recipient IgG against donor antigens causing complement-mediated thrombosis (hyperacute rejection) Why this is right: Preexisting anti-HLA/ABO antibodies rapidly fix complement, causing endothelial injury and thrombosis immediately upon reperfusion. Why the others are wrong: A/B. Cause later acute rejection.

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: Ten days after a kidney transplant, creatinine rises. Biopsy shows interstitial lymphocytic infiltrates with tubulitis and endothelialitis. C4d staining is minimal. Which rejection pattern is most likely?

options.A: Immediate onset.
options.B: Late, fibrotic changes.
options.C: Acute T-cell–mediated rejection via direct allorecognition
options.D: Would show C4d/DSA.
options.E: Not a solid-organ phenomenon.

rationales.E: Acute T-cell–mediated rejection via direct allorecognition Why this is right: The timing and histology (tubulitis/endothelialitis, scant C4d) point to cellular rejection driven by recipient T cells recognizing donor MHC. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A renal transplant recipient develops graft dysfunction 3 weeks post-op. Biopsy shows neutrophils in peritubular capillaries and strong C4d deposition; donor-specific anti-HLA antibodies are detected. Which mechanism is operating?

options.A: Delayed-type hypersensitivity
options.B: Acute antibody-mediated rejection with complement activation
options.C: Chronic rejection
options.D: Hyperacute rejection
options.E: Drug toxicity Correct: B

rationales.E: Acute antibody-mediated rejection with complement activation Why this is right: C4d marks classical pathway activation by donor-specific antibodies in peritubular capillaries. Why the others are wrong: A/C/D/E. Do not match timing and C4d positivity.

questions.subtopic: Neutrophils

questions.stem: Two years after lung transplant, FEV1 declines. Biopsy shows concentric intimal fibrosis of small arteries and bronchiolitis obliterans. Which process is most consistent?

options.A: Chronic rejection with immune-mediated vascular smooth muscle proliferation and fibrosis
options.B: Acute cellular rejection
options.C: Hyperacute rejection
options.D: Primary graft dysfunction (ischemia–reperfusion)
options.E: Infection can mimic decline but biopsy shows chronic lesions.

rationales.E: Chronic rejection with immune-mediated vascular smooth muscle proliferation and fibrosis Why this is right: Chronic rejection presents months–years later with progressive fibrosis and vasculopathy/bronchiolitis obliterans. Why the others are wrong: B/C/D. Incorrect timing or pathology.

questions.stem: A patient develops diffuse rash, jaundice, and watery diarrhea 3 weeks after allogeneic hematopoietic stem-cell transplant. Liver biopsy shows lymphocytic portal tract inflammation. Which mechanism explains this syndrome?

options.A: Recipient T cells attacking donor tissues
options.B: Preformed antibodies causing thrombosis of hepatic vessels
options.C: Chronic rejection of liver tissue
options.D: Direct toxicity of calcineurin inhibitors
options.E: Donor T cells attacking recipient tissues (GVHD) Correct: E

rationales.E: Donor T cells attacking recipient tissues (GVHD) Why this is right: In GVHD, immunocompetent donor T cells react against recipient antigens in skin, liver, and gut. Why the others are wrong: A/C. Reverse direction or organ context. B/D. Do not cause the triad described.

questions.stem: A newly transplanted patient receives tacrolimus and mycophenolate. Which statement best describes how tacrolimus helps prevent acute cellular rejection?

options.A: Blocks IL-6 receptor signaling
options.B: Depletes B cells via CD20
options.C: Inhibits calcineurin, preventing NFAT-mediated IL-2 transcription in T cells
options.D: Neutralizes TNF-α to maintain granulomas
options.E: Inhibits JAK–STAT signaling downstream of IFN-γ Correct: C

rationales.E: Inhibits calcineurin, preventing NFAT-mediated IL-2 transcription in T cells Why this is right: Calcineurin inhibitors block IL-2 production, blunting clonal T-cell expansion critical for rejection. Why the others are wrong: A/B/D/E. Different drug mechanisms.

questions.stem: A kidney recipient develops rising creatinine and biopsy-proven acute cellular rejection at day 12. Which immediate therapy is most appropriate?

options.A: Abacavir is unrelated.
options.B: Would worsen rejection.
options.C: IL-5 targets eosinophils; IVIG is for humoral disorders.
options.D: Administer high-dose corticosteroids, with consideration of T-cell–depleting therapy if refractory
options.E: Not a rejection treatment. Topic: B Cell & T Cell Activation [No high-yield questions available] Subtopic: B Cell Traffic and Activation

rationales.E: Administer high-dose corticosteroids, with consideration of T-cell–depleting therapy if refractory Why this is right: First-line treatment for acute cellular rejection is pulse steroids; refractory cases may need anti-thymocyte globulin or similar T-cell–depleting agents.
