questions.stem: A 35-year-old woman with relapsing–remitting multiple sclerosis starts a new oral agent and within 2 weeks develops lymphopenia without bone-marrow suppression. Lymph node size is normal. Flow cytometry shows a drop in circulating naïve B cells (IgD+CD27−) but preserved counts within a node biopsy. She has increased infections with respiratory viruses. Which mechanism best explains the fall in blood B cells?

options.A: Affects synapse stability, not global egress.
options.B: CXCR5 loss impairs follicular homing, not retention.
options.C: BAFF supports survival; excess doesn’t explain trapping.
options.D: Blockade of S1P1-mediated egress traps lymphocytes within nodes
options.E: FDCs display antigen; they don’t control egress.

rationales.E: Blockade of S1P1-mediated egress traps lymphocytes within nodes Why this is right: S1P1 guides lymphocyte exit from lymph nodes; functional antagonism keeps B (and T) cells sequestered in nodes, reducing blood counts without marrow failure. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: Lymph node imaging in a vaccinated adult shows naïve B cells entering follicles (CXCL13-rich) but, after antigen encounter, the activated B cells migrate to the T–B border to seek T-cell help. Which receptor change on B cells enables this relocation?

options.A: Would impair movement to the border.
options.B: CXCR5 gets them into follicles, not toward T cells.
options.C: Upregulation of CCR7 to sense CCL19/CCL21 in the T-cell zone
options.D: Affects egress timing rather than border migration.
options.E: CR2 lowers activation threshold but doesn’t drive migration.

rationales.E: Upregulation of CCR7 to sense CCL19/CCL21 in the T-cell zone Why this is right: Antigen-primed B cells increase CCR7, moving toward the T-cell area to receive CD40L/cytokine help. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Treg cells (Regulatory T cells)

questions.stem: Shortly after subcutaneous vaccination, opsonized viral particles are detected at the lymph node subcapsular sinus. B cells near the follicular edge acquire antigen from a specialized myeloid population that captures complement-coated particles and ferries them to follicles. Which cell is this?

options.A: Classical dendritic cell
options.B: Subcapsular sinus macrophage (CD169+)
options.C: Neutrophil
options.D: Eosinophil
options.E: Plasmacytoid dendritic cell Correct: B

rationales.E: Subcapsular sinus macrophage (CD169+) Why this is right: SCS macrophages sample lymph, bind complement-coated antigen, and deliver it to follicles/FDCs for B-cell encounter. Why the others are wrong: A/E. Present peptides to T cells rather than ferry native antigen to follicles. C/D. Not primary antigen couriers in nodes.

questions.subtopic: Treg cells (Regulatory T cells)

questions.stem: A 4-year-old boy with recurrent Pneumocystis pneumonia has normal B-cell numbers and intact antigen binding but cannot class switch or form germinal centers. Which interaction at the T–B border is most likely defective?

options.A: Preserved in the stem.
options.B: Effector, not helper, function.
options.C: Can augment activation but cannot replace CD40L.
options.D: CD40L on activated CD4 T cells engaging CD40 on B cells
options.E: BAFF supports survival, not T cell help.

rationales.E: CD40L on activated CD4 T cells engaging CD40 on B cells Why this is right: CD40–CD40L delivers essential “Signal 2” for class switching and germinal center formation; loss causes hyper-IgM phenotype. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: Germinal center mapping shows proliferating centroblasts in a “dark zone” and selection of higher-affinity clones in a “light zone.” Which chemokine–receptor pairing primarily retains proliferating centroblasts in the dark zone?

options.A: Light zone/follicle retention.
options.B: CXCL12–CXCR4
options.C: T-zone homing.
options.D: Egress cue.
options.E: Lowers activation threshold but not zonal positioning. Subtopic: T-independent Activation Q: Why are conjugate vaccines more effective than polysaccharide vaccines in infants? [Restored Pathology]

rationales.E: CXCL12–CXCR4 Why this is right: Dark zone centroblasts express CXCR4 and localize to CXCL12; selection in the light zone depends more on CXCR5–CXCL13. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: A 12-month-old receives a pure polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae but develops pneumonia months later. Serology shows poor response to the vaccine, with mainly low-affinity IgM and minimal memory. Which property of the original antigen best explains this outcome?

options.A: Strong peptide epitopes recruit Th1 help
options.B: TLR signals alone don’t provide cognate T-cell help.
options.C: Highly repetitive epitopes cross-link BCRs (TI-2), eliciting poor memory in infants
options.D: Describes conjugate vaccines (not used here).
options.E: Presentation by HLA-DQ2 elicits Tfh cells Correct: C

rationales.E: Highly repetitive epitopes cross-link BCRs (TI-2), eliciting poor memory in infants Why this is right: TI-2 antigens (capsular polysaccharides) strongly cross-link BCRs on marginal zone B cells, producing mostly IgM with weak memory—especially poor in infants. Why the others are wrong: A/E. Polysaccharides lack peptide for MHC II.

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: In vitro, human B cells produce IgM when exposed to high-dose lipopolysaccharide, even without T cells. Which signal most directly explains this T-independent activation?

options.A: IL-4–mediated class switching
options.B: CD40–CD40L engagement from T cells
options.C: Antigen presentation to Tfh cells in germinal centers
options.D: B cells don’t rely on FcγR cross-linking for primary activation.
options.E: TLR4 engagement by LPS providing a TI-1 signal that synergizes with BCR Correct: E

rationales.E: TLR4 engagement by LPS providing a TI-1 signal that synergizes with BCR Why this is right: TI-1 antigens (e.g., LPS) activate B cells via TLRs; at high dose, they can polyclonally activate B cells independent of T-cell help. Why the others are wrong: A/B/C. Require T-cell help.

questions.subtopic: T-independent Activation

questions.stem: A 28-year-old asplenic man develops sepsis from Streptococcus pneumoniae. He had not received conjugate vaccines. Loss of which B-cell population most compromises T-independent responses to encapsulated bacteria?

options.A: Splenic marginal zone B cells
options.B: Maintain serum IgG but aren’t the TI-2 first responders. C/E. T cells aren’t central to TI-2.
options.C: Follicular helper T cells
options.D: Produce type I IFN, not polysaccharide IgM.
options.E: Naïve CD8+ T cells Correct: A

rationales.E: Splenic marginal zone B cells Why this is right: Marginal zone B cells rapidly respond to TI-2 polysaccharides from encapsulated organisms, producing IgM; splenectomy removes this defense. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Detection and Response to Danger Signals

questions.stem: A pediatrician switches from a polysaccharide vaccine to a conjugate vaccine (polysaccharide linked to diphtheria toxoid) to protect toddlers. Which mechanism explains the improved immunogenicity?

options.A: Polysaccharides aren’t presented on MHC I. B/C. Nonspecific signals don’t replace cognate T-cell help.
options.B: LPS contamination activates TLR4
options.C: Bystander activation from IL-12 and IFN-γ
options.D: B cell internalizes the conjugate, presents carrier peptides on MHC II to Tfh cells, receives CD40L help → class switching and memory
options.E: Misses the essential T-cell help.

rationales.E: B cell internalizes the conjugate, presents carrier peptides on MHC II to Tfh cells, receives CD40L help → class switching and memory Why this is right: Conjugates convert a TI polysaccharide into a T-dependent response, enabling germinal centers, class switching, and memory. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Main Purposes of the Immune System and Clinical Disease

questions.stem: In a vaccine study, opsonizing C3d is covalently attached to a polysaccharide antigen. B cells respond at lower antigen concentrations. Which B-cell surface molecule binds C3d to enhance activation?

options.A: Costimulatory receptor for T-dependent help.
options.B: CR2 (CD21)
options.C: On T cells, not B-cell coreceptor complex.
options.D: Fc receptor on myeloid cells.
options.E: BAFF/APRIL receptor, not C3d-binding.

rationales.E: CR2 (CD21) Why this is right: CR2 on B cells binds C3d-tagged antigen, co-ligating with the BCR to lower activation thresholds. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: B Cell Traffic and Activation

questions.stem: An elderly patient receives a plain polysaccharide vaccine. Antibody titers rise but wane within months; memory recall to boost is poor. Which feature of T-independent responses best explains this?

options.A: Strong germinal center reaction generates short-lived cells only
options.B: Robust affinity maturation produces unstable antibodies
options.C: Minimal germinal center formation → limited class switching/affinity maturation and weak memory
options.D: Excessive TLR signaling deletes memory B cells
options.E: Polyclonal T-cell activation exhausts Tfh cells Correct: C

rationales.E: Minimal germinal center formation → limited class switching/affinity maturation and weak memory Why this is right: TI responses largely bypass germinal centers, yielding short-lived IgM and scant memory. Why the others are wrong: A/B. Contradict the TI biology. D/E. Not defining features of TI vaccines.

questions.subtopic: Detection and Response to Danger Signals

questions.stem: A 7-year-old girl has recurrent bacterial sinopulmonary infections. Sequencing reveals a TACI mutation (TNFRSF13B). Her responses to polysaccharide antigens are poor despite normal T-cell counts. Which defect best explains her phenotype?

options.A: Failure of BAFF/APRIL signaling that augments TI responses and supports class switching
options.B: Would cause classic X-linked hyper-IgM.
options.C: Explains TI-1 LPS responsiveness only. D/E. Not specific to TI polysaccharide immunity. Correct-letter distribution for Topic “B Cell & T Cell Activation”: A=3, B=3, C=3, D=3, E=2 Topic: Killing Mechanisms [No high-yield questions available] Subtopic: Lytic granules
options.D: Defective β2-microglobulin
options.E: Failure of FcRn-mediated IgG salvage Correct: A

rationales.E: Failure of BAFF/APRIL signaling that augments TI responses and supports class switching Why this is right: TACI binds BAFF/APRIL; mutations impair B-cell survival and TI-enhanced class switching, causing poor polysaccharide responses (a CVID spectrum). Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A lung carcinoma line downregulates class I MHC and becomes resistant to CD8+ T-cell recognition. Coculture with healthy NK cells triggers rapid target-cell death that is prevented by concanamycin A (vacuolar ATPase inhibitor that disrupts cytotoxic granule function). Which effector mechanism most directly mediates this NK-dependent killing?

options.A: NK cells can use TRAIL/FasL, but granule exocytosis is primary here.
options.B: ADCC uses FcγRIII (CD16), not FcεRI.
options.C: Complement is not the dominant NK mechanism.
options.D: TNF-α is not the principal pathway in this assay.
options.E: Perforin and granzyme release at the NK–tumor synapse Correct: E

rationales.E: Perforin and granzyme release at the NK–tumor synapse Why this is right: NK cells respond to “missing self” and kill via polarized exocytosis of perforin and granzymes—blocked by concanamycin A. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: In a live-cell imaging assay, antigen-specific CD8+ T cells form stable synapses with peptide–MHC I+ targets. When extracellular Ca2+ is chelated with EGTA, synapse formation persists but no target apoptosis occurs and granules fail to dock at the membrane. Which step of cytotoxic T-cell function is most Ca2+-dependent and thus inhibited?

options.A: Exocytosis of lytic granules containing perforin and granzymes
options.B: TCR recognition of peptide–MHC I
options.C: Expression of IFN-γ and TNF-α genes
options.D: Formation of immunologic synapse via LFA-1/ICAM-1
options.E: Fas ligand transcription and trafficking Correct: A

rationales.E: Exocytosis of lytic granules containing perforin and granzymes Why this is right: Granule fusion with the membrane is Ca2+-dependent; chelation prevents granule release despite intact recognition and adhesion. Why the others are wrong: B/D. Recognition/adhesion occur despite EGTA. C/E. Transcription/trafficking are less acutely Ca2+-dependent than degranulation.

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A virology lab tracks molecular events during CTL killing. Seconds after synapse formation, a serine protease enters the cytosol of the target cell, cleaves caspase-3, and truncates Bid to tBid, amplifying mitochondrial apoptosis. Which molecule most directly performs these actions?

options.A: Forms pores but is not a protease.
options.B: Initiator caspase in death receptor signaling. C/E. Cathepsin D/Granzyme A do not perform the described cleavages.
options.C: Cathepsin D
options.D: Granzyme B
options.E: Granzyme A Correct: D

rationales.E: Granzyme B Why this is right: Granzyme B activates executioner caspases and cleaves Bid, linking extrinsic and intrinsic pathways after perforin-mediated entry. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: Researchers quantify CTL degranulation by staining surface LAMP-1 (CD107a). After peptide stimulation, which finding indicates effective delivery of the lytic granule machinery to the immunologic synapse?

options.A: Retained perforin doesn’t indicate release.
options.B: FasL changes don’t measure granule exocytosis. D/E. Reflect adhesion/complement, not CTL degranulation.
options.C: Transient increase of CD107a on the CTL surface as granules fuse with the membrane
options.D: Increased target-cell expression of ICAM-1
options.E: Increased serum C3a/C5a levels Correct: C

rationales.E: Transient increase of CD107a on the CTL surface as granules fuse with the membrane Why this is right: CD107a becomes surface-exposed during granule fusion, serving as a degranulation readout. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A CTL line efficiently kills peptide-pulsed targets. When perforin function is specifically inhibited, killing decreases but is partially restored by adding agonistic anti-Fas to the culture. Which conclusion is best supported?

options.A: TNF-α does not fully replace perforin/Fas.
options.B: Complement does not mediate CTL cytotoxicity.
options.C: FasL can induce apoptosis independently.
options.D: Adhesion remains intact here. Subtopic: Inducing apoptosis
options.E: CTLs use both granule exocytosis and Fas–FasL pathways; inhibiting one can be partly compensated by the other Correct: E

rationales.E: CTLs use both granule exocytosis and Fas–FasL pathways; inhibiting one can be partly compensated by the other Why this is right: CTLs deploy perforin/granzymes and FasL; blocking perforin reduces killing but Fas agonism can trigger apoptosis via the death receptor pathway. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Antibody Function in Host Defense and Immunopathology

questions.stem: A 6-year-old girl has chronic, nonmalignant lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly, recurrent autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, and elevated double-negative (CD3+CD4−CD8−) T cells. In vitro, her T cells fail to undergo activation-induced cell death when exposed to agonistic anti-Fas antibody. Which defect best explains her syndrome?

options.A: Explains HLH, not this phenotype. B/D/E. Do not produce the classic ALPS triad with Fas-insensitive AICD.
options.B: STAT1 gain-of-function with hyper–IFN-γ signaling
options.C: Fas (CD95) death receptor pathway mutation causing ALPS
options.D: IL-2 receptor α (CD25) deficiency causing Treg failure
options.E: TAP deficiency causing reduced MHC I expression Correct: C

rationales.E: Fas (CD95) death receptor pathway mutation causing ALPS Why this is right: Autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome features impaired Fas-mediated apoptosis, DNT-cell expansion, and autoimmune cytopenias. Why the others are wrong:

questions.subtopic: Innate Immune Cells

questions.stem: Cultured T cells are activated and then exposed to Fas agonist. Within minutes, the death-inducing signaling complex (DISC) forms and initiator caspases are cleaved. Which initiator caspase is most directly activated to trigger the extrinsic apoptosis cascade in this setting?

options.A: Caspase-9 is intrinsic/mitochondrial.
options.B: Caspase-8
options.C: Inflammasome IL-1β maturation.
options.D: ER stress (less established in humans).
options.E: Executioner caspase downstream, not initiator.

rationales.E: Caspase-8 Why this is right: Fas engagement recruits FADD and activates caspase-8 (± caspase-10), which then activates executioner caspases. Why the others are wrong:

questions.stem: A colorectal carcinoma line overexpresses decoy receptors (DcR1/DcR2) that bind TRAIL but lack functional death domains. The cells resist NK-induced apoptosis despite intact granule exocytosis. Which cytotoxic pathway is specifically inhibited by this tumor adaptation?

options.A: Complement MAC on tumor membranes
options.B: Perforin pore formation and granzyme delivery
options.C: Intrinsic apoptosis triggered by DNA damage
options.D: TRAIL–death receptor (DR4/DR5)–mediated extrinsic apoptosis
options.E: IgE-mediated eosinophil degranulation Correct: D

rationales.E: TRAIL–death receptor (DR4/DR5)–mediated extrinsic apoptosis Why this is right: Decoy TRAIL receptors sequester ligand and prevent signaling through DR4/DR5, blunting NK/T-cell death receptor killing. Why the others are wrong: A/B/C/E. Not the pathway blocked by TRAIL decoys.

questions.stem: A follicular lymphoma overexpresses BCL2 and resists both chemotherapy and T-cell–mediated killing. A BH3-mimetic drug is started. Which mitochondrial event most directly restores apoptosis sensitivity in these tumor cells?

options.A: Inhibition of caspase-8 at the DISC
options.B: The opposite of apoptosis.
options.C: Bax/Bak–mediated mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization releasing cytochrome c to activate caspase-9
options.D: Autophagy is not the core apoptotic trigger.
options.E: Increased expression of FLIP to block initiator caspases Correct: C

rationales.E: Bax/Bak–mediated mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization releasing cytochrome c to activate caspase-9 Why this is right: BH3 mimetics antagonize BCL2, allowing Bax/Bak pore formation, cytochrome c release, apoptosome assembly, and caspase activation. Why the others are wrong: A/E. DISC regulation is extrinsic.

questions.subtopic: Treg cells (Regulatory T cells)

questions.stem: Peripheral blood from a teen with lymphadenopathy shows expansion of CD3+CD4−CD8− T cells. In vitro, anti-CD3 activation followed by anti-Fas–induced apoptosis fails, whereas perforin/granzyme–mediated killing of peptide-pulsed targets is intact. Which additional lab finding best supports the suspected diagnosis?

options.A: NK numbers may be normal.
options.B: TAP/MHC I defects give CD8 lymphopenia.
options.C: Describes CGD, not ALPS.
options.D: Not characteristic.
options.E: Failure of patient T cells to die after Fas agonist exposure across multiple assays (defective activation-induced cell death) Correct: E

rationales.E: Failure of patient T cells to die after Fas agonist exposure across multiple assays (defective activation-induced cell death) Why this is right: ALPS shows impaired Fas-dependent AICD with DNT-cell expansion and preserved granule-mediated killing. Why the others are wrong:

questions.topic: T Cell Receptors and the MHC
questions.subtopic: Interaction of APCs and Processed Peptides with T Cell Receptors

questions.stem: A herpesvirus gene upregulates cellular c-FLIP in infected epithelial cells. In co-culture, activated CD8+ T cells form synapses but fail to induce apoptosis via the death receptor pathway; perforin/granzyme killing remains intact. Which step is most directly inhibited by c-FLIP?

options.A: Perforin pore formation
options.B: Activation of caspase-8 at the DISC following Fas engagement
options.C: Release of cytochrome c from mitochondria
options.D: Executioner caspase-3 cleavage by granzyme B
options.E: NK-cell recognition of missing self Correct: B
